conclusion: Interpret the situation when switch S is open.
The circuit path through the 10 Ω resistor is broken.
The 20 Ω resistor, the voltmeter, and the resistor R form the only current-carrying loop with the source.
Voltmeter is assumed ideal, so infinite resistance.
Because the voltmeter draws no current, the 20 Ω resistor and points a–b effectively see the same potential: the voltmeter reading is the potential difference across the 20 Ω resistor, namely 6 V.
Use Ohm’s law to relate current and resistance in the open-switch condition: Current I_open = 6 V / 20 Ω = 0.30 A flows through R and the source.
The terminal voltage of the source then is V_terminal = ε – I_open · r.
When S is closed, the 10 Ω resistor becomes active and is now in parallel with the 20 Ω resistor.
Equivalent resistance of 10 Ω ∥ 20 Ω is Req = (10 × 20)/(10 + 20) = 6 ⅔ Ω.
Req is in series with R and r.
Form two equations with the unknowns ε and r obtained from the open-switch condition and the total voltage in the closed-switch condition.
Solve the equations to find the new current.
Voltage between a and b with S closed equals I_closed × Req.
Carrying out the algebra leads to: I_closed = 0.75 A.
Vab_closed = I_closed × Req = 0.75 A × 6 ⅔ Ω = 5 V.
The potential difference between points a and b when the switch S is closed is 5 V.
